prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LkCa15 continuum Band 3 at 0.1arcsec resolution
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations at high angular resolution of the disk around LkCa 15.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission at 0.1" resolution for the transitional disk of LkCa15. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 13CO, and C18O in their J=1-0 transition:
(1) Basebands 1,2 and 3 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum.
(2) Baseband 4 BW is kept as wide as possible (1.875 GHz per polarization) but with good velocity resolution (2.7 km/s) to spectrally resolve in a few channels the lines of a few km/s width.

(1) A single pointing is required since the disk of LkCa15 has an spatial extent of about 2.5", which fits well within the 60" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to radially resolve the ring of emission that characterizes LkCa15 with more than 5 resolutions elements in case the emission is as broad as ~80AU (FWHM), as it seems to appear from previous ALMA observations.
(3) Since the disk of LkCa15 has an spatial extent of about 2.5" and since the largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 3 with the proposed configuration is ~1.5", these observations will suffer from spatial filtering. However, a different science goal is presented with this proposal to recover all spatial scales from the LkCa15 disk at this frequency.

(1) Our sensitivity request is motivated by the brightness temperature sensitivity achieved in our VLA observations of LkCa15, for which an RMS sensitivity of 0.4 K in a 0.075" beam at a wavelength of 7mm was obtained. In order to be sensitive to the same column density of material with these ALMA Band 3 observations, we request the same brightness temperature sensitivity.
(2) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of two spectral lines (13CO and C18O in the J=(1-0) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~3sigma if they have peak fluxes of 11mJy or brighter.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LkCa15 continuum Band 6 at 0.1arcsec resolution
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations at high angular resolution of the disk around LkCa 15.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission at 0.1" resolution for the transitional disk of LkCa15. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, in their J=2-1 transition:
(1) Basebands 2 and 4 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum. (2) Baseband 1 is split in two windows of 468.8 MHz BW each. The first window observes the continuum with a low data rate. The second window observes 12CO(2-1) with high velocity resolution (0.6 km/s), sufficient to spectrally resolve the few km/s wide lines. (3) Finally, baseband 3 is split into 4 windows of 468.8 MHz BW each, to observe 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) in the same baseband with 1.3 km/s velocity resolution, as well as the continuum in the other two bands. These lines are not critical to the proposal goal , but the correlator versatility allows for its simultaneous observation while keeping the aggregate continuum BW on this baseband to the maximum of 1.875 GHz per polarization.

(1) A single pointing is required since the disk of LkCa15 has an spatial extent of about 2.5", which fits well within the 25" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to radially resolve the ring of emission that characterizes LkCa15 with more than 5 resolutions elements in case the emission is as broad as ~80AU (FWHM), as it seems to appear from previous ALMA observations.
(3) Since the disk of LkCa15 has an spatial extent of about 2.5" and since the largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 6 with the proposed configuration is ~2.0", these observations will suffer from spatial filtering. However, a different science goal is presented with this proposal to recover all spatial scales from the LkCa15 disk at this frequency.

(1) Our sensitivity request is motivated by the brightness temperature sensitivity achieved in our VLA observations of LkCa15, for which an RMS sensitivity of 0.4 K in a 0.075" beam at a wavelength of 7mm was obtained. In order to be sensitive to a similar column density of material with these ALMA Band 6 observations, we request a brightness temperature sensitivity of 0.1K (four times better than VLA with a similar beam size of 0.1"), which would allow to trace four times fainter emission in the inner cavity and outer disk of LkCa15.
(2) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of various spectral lines (12CO, 13CO, and C18O in the J=(2-1) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~3sigma if they have peak fluxes of 11mJy or brighter.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LkCa15 continuum Band 3 for large scale emission
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations at low spatial resolution to recover the large scales of the disk around LkCa 15.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission at 0.1" resolution for the transitional disk of LkCa15. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 13CO, and C18O in their J=1-0 transition:
(1) Basebands 1,2 and 3 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum.
(2) Baseband 4 BW is kept as wide as possible (1.875 GHz per polarization) but with good velocity resolution (2.7 km/s) to spectrally resolve in a few channels the lines of a few km/s width.

(1) A single pointing is required since the disk of LkCa15 has an spatial extent of about 2.5", which fits well within the 60" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution of 0.4" is defined to resolve the cavity that characterizes LkCa15, which has about 0.7" in diameter (~100 AU at the distance of the star).
(3) With this configuration, we will be able to recover the large spatial scales that will be filtered-out by our proposed high-resolution observations with a 0.1" beam. These observations have a "largest angular scale" of several arcseconds, and as the spatial extent of LkCa15 is about 2.5", these observations will help recover all spatial scales from the disk.

(1) Our sensitivity request is motivated by the brightness temperature sensitivity achieved in our VLA observations of LkCa15, for which an RMS sensitivity of 0.4 K in a 0.075" beam at a wavelength of 7mm was obtained. In order to be sensitive to a less abundant column density of material with these ALMA Band 3 observations, we request a brightness temperature sensitivity of 0.03K (x10 better than VLA observations) which would allow to trace much fainter emission in the outer disk of LkCa15.
(2) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of two spectral lines (13CO and C18O in the J=(1-0) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~3sigma if they have peak fluxes of 11mJy or brighter.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LkCa15 continuum Band 6 for large scale emission
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations at low spatial resolution to recover the large scales of the disk around LkCa 15.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission at 0.1" resolution for the transitional disk of LkCa15. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, in their J=2-1 transition:
(1) Basebands 2 and 4 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum. (2) Baseband 1 is split in two windows of 468.8 MHz BW each. The first window observes the continuum with a low data rate. The second window observes 12CO(2-1) with high velocity resolution (0.6 km/s), sufficient to spectrally resolve the few km/s wide lines. (3) Finally, baseband 3 is split into 4 windows of 468.8 MHz BW each, to observe 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) in the same baseband with 1.3 km/s velocity resolution, as well as the continuum in the other two bands. These lines are not critical to the proposal goal , but the correlator versatility allows for its simultaneous observation while keeping the aggregate continuum BW on this baseband to the maximum of 1.875 GHz per polarization.

(1) A single pointing is required since the disk of LkCa15 has an spatial extent of about 2.5", which fits well within the 25" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution of 0.4" is defined to resolve the cavity that characterizes LkCa15, which has about 0.7" in diameter (~100 AU at the distance of the star).
(3) With this configuration, we will be able to recover the large spatial scales that will be filtered-out by our proposed high-resolution observations with a 0.1" beam. These observations have a "largest angular scale" of several arcseconds, and as the spatial extent of LkCa15 is about 2.5", these observations will help recover all spatial scales from the disk.

(1) Our sensitivity request is motivated by the brightness temperature sensitivity achieved in our VLA observations of LkCa15, for which an RMS sensitivity of 0.4 K in a 0.075" beam at a wavelength of 7mm was obtained. In order to be sensitive to a less abundant column density of material with these ALMA Band 6 observations, we request a brightness temperature sensitivity of 0.01K (x40 better than VLA observations) which would allow to trace much fainter emission in the outer disk of LkCa15.
(2) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of various spectral lines (12CO, 13CO, and C18O in the J=(2-1) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~3sigma if they have peak fluxes of 15mJy or brighter.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The morphology and spectral energy distribution of transition disks show signatures of localized depletion of material that can be linked to the presence of planet(s). One of the most extensively studied transitional disks is LkCa15: near-IR and sub-mm imaging reveal a gap of 50AU radius, while the presence of a planetary-mass companion (6-15MJup) orbiting at 20AU from the star has been inferred within the gap. Given this observational facts, LkCa15 is an excellent laboratory to study particle trapping induced by a massive planet. In the planet-disk interaction scenario, particle trapping not only hinges on the planet properties, but strongly depends on the disk turbulent viscosity, a critical parameter to understand disk evolution. We propose to use 0.1" (14AU resolution) ALMA observations at 1.3 and 2.7 mm, to radially resolve the ring-structure of LkCa15. By measuring the dust density distribution at different wavelengths, in combination with our 7 mm observations at high angular resolution (75mas), we will determine the level of turbulent viscosity in the disk by linking the expected behavior of a planet-induced particle trap with current models of dust growth and evolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
